awd_titl_txt: CRII:SCH:RUI: A Digital Identity System for Accelerating Medical Communications within Rare Disease Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Patient identity matching is a process that locates a patient in a healthcare database using a unique set of personal information. Rare diseases are conditions that affect fewer than 200,000 people in the US, and due to the small patient populations, they receive significantly less scientific and commercial attention compared to more commonly studied medical conditions. As a result, highly motivated and active patient communities often form around rare diseases, creating and maintaining patient registries for patients to share data and knowledge about their conditions to promote disease discovery. However, many registries have been one-off solutions that identify patients in disparate ways, creating a major barrier to linking patients across multiple highly centralized registries. The objective of this project is to address this need by developing an interoperable and efficient identity system to support necessary communications around rare diseases, while simultaneously providing interdisciplinary research experience to computer science undergraduate students.

This project will design, deploy, and evaluate a digital identity system driven by interoperability across data management systems. The goal of the proposed approach is to accelerate the patient identification process by creating unique representations of patient identities and a supporting platform that facilitate the management and exchanges of those identities to ensure interoperability. The technical aims of the project are divided into three threads. The first thread creates a standardized digital identity model for rare diseases, which aims to uniquely represent patients without directly exposing sensitive, ambiguous patient identifying information to significantly reduce patient mismatching rate. The second thread develops a Rare Disease Identity System (RDIS) infrastructure, which will enable uniform and interoperable representations and transactions of patient identity to accelerate clinical communications. The third thread focuses on integrated evaluation of RDIS with the use of the digital identity model created in the first thread. In particular, the overall effectiveness of the system will be evaluated based on the ease of identity collection and verification process, the scalability of the system in terms of the overall and average throughput of transacted synthetic patient profiles, and the average turnaround time it takes to identify a subset of patient profiles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project was launched with the key goal of enhancing medical communications within rare disease communities through the development of a decentralized digital identity system. Our efforts focused on leveraging blockchain and distributed ledger technologies to facilitate secure and efficient data sharing among patients, healthcare providers, and researchers.


Intellectual Merit: The project's intellectual endeavors were centered on creating a digital identity framework that would allow rare disease patients to safely and easily share their health information across different healthcare systems without compromising their privacy or the security of their data. By implementing a standardized digital identity model that follows open web standards, the project has contributed significantly to the field of computer science and its interdisciplinary application, particularly in the context of applying blockchain technology to healthcare. This model demonstrates the potential of blockchain to go beyond its traditional financial applications and address pressing challenges in healthcare data management.


Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this project are particularly significant for the rare disease community, which often struggles with fragmented healthcare systems and inconsistent data management practices. By improving the interoperability of healthcare data, our project has the potential to facilitate faster and more accurate diagnoses, improved treatment coordination, and ultimately better health outcomes for patients with rare diseases. Moreover, the project has made substantial contributions to education and workforce development. We involved undergraduate students in cutting-edge research, providing them with valuable hands-on experience in applying blockchain technologies to real-world problems in healthcare. These students have not only gained technical skills but also learned about the ethical considerations and societal impacts of their work, preparing them to become thoughtful and innovative leaders in their future careers.

Summary of Outcomes: Throughout the duration of the award, we successfully developed and tested a prototype of the digital identity system by analyzing the needs from the rare disease research community. We have disseminated our findings and technical developments through various channels, including publications in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at international conferences, contributing to the academic and practical discourse on the use of blockchain in healthcare. Additionally, the project has highlighted the importance of privacy, security, and patient-centric approaches in the design of healthcare technologies. These insights are critical as we continue to explore the potential of blockchain and other technologies to enhance healthcare delivery and medical research.


In conclusion, this project has advanced our understanding of how innovative technologies can be employed to solve complex problems in healthcare, particularly for underserved populations such as the rare disease community. The outcomes of this project not only have implications for the future of healthcare technology but also underscore the critical role of interdisciplinary research and collaboration in driving scientific and societal progress.


"This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content."


Last Modified: 04/29/2024
Modified by: Peng Zhang
